Key Arguments: The existing legislation does not require amendments as digital platform providers have their own precise and transparent code.
The proposed legislation would weaken freedom of speech, a fundamental human right.
The Amendment Bill appears to promote censorship rather than protect the public.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation in the Bill are vague and subjective.
The Bill allows for ad hoc decision-making without sufficient scrutiny or safeguards.
The exemptions for professional media, educational institutions, and government from the Bill's operation are concerning.
Notable Quotes: Signatories should not be compelled by Governments or other parties to remove content solely on the basis of its alleged falsity if the content would not otherwise be unlawful.
This Amendment Bill seems to be more about bringing censorship out in to the open than protecting the poor gullible people of Australia.
Far too much of this Amendment Bill is vague, open to interpretation, and prone to abuse.
Freedom of thought and freedom of speech are inalienable human rights; this proposed legislation seeks to curtail them and should be quashed.
